text.p: The section name Binary Distribution in the navigation bar is actually a misnomer - you will compile xindy kernel source code during installation. But you will download and use a binary distribution of the compiler to do that.

rightcol.p: The Download Area is at SourceForge.

Fetch
xindy-2.1.tar.gz
xindy-2.1-platform.tar.gz, where platform is appropriate for your system.
xindy-make-rules-0.2.tar.gz
If you want to use xindy on HP-UX or SunOS 4, you'll have to fetch the 2.0 release. Current binary distributions don't exist for these platforms.

If you want to use xindy on Windows or OS/2, you'll have to fetch the 2.0 release, too. The rest of this installation instructions won't work under these operating systems, though. Your best bet is getting GNU make (e.g., from Cygwin) and adapting the Makefiles. Your help to improve that miserable situation would be really welcome.

ol.li: Unpack xindy-2.1.tar.gz. The directory xindy is created.
Create a symlink current: ln -s xindy-2.1 current
xindy will be installed in /usr/local. If you don't like this, change it in Makefile.install.

Create the format:
make all make gzipped
During make all, there will be warnings about an unspecified installation directory. Ignore them.
(Optional) Run tests: make testsuite This will end with the message that tests ex1 and ex2 have failed. That is a known problem with the tests, not with xindy.

By default, the xindy command will be installed in /usr/local/bin and auxiliary files in /usr/local/lib/xindy. You might have changed these directories, as explained above. make install Most probably, you can only do this as root.

(Optional) You might want to copy the man pages to appropriate directories, e.g.,
cd /usr/local cp lib/xindy/doc/*.1 man/man1 cd -
If you don't have GNU make, get it and install it. (Linux users have it by default, the others should know.)
If you have changed the installation directory of xindy, you need to adapt the settings in Makefile.

rightcol.p: Three user commands have been installed, makeindex4, makeindex.sh and xindy.
makeindex4 comes with an associated man page, makeindex.sh has a good usage message, and tutorial and reference documentation exist for xindy.
Currently the best way to learn about xindy usage is copying an example index style, and changing it. A good one is in xindy-make-rules-0.2.
